citation_title: The Minimum Wage and Search Effort
topics:
Labor Economics

Labor Supply and Demand

Unemployment and Immigration
abstract: Labor market search-and-matching models posit supply-side responses to minimum wage increases that may lead to improved matches and lessen or even reverse negative employment eﬀects. Yet there is sparse empirical evidence on this crucial assumption. Using event study analysis of recent minimum wage increases, we ﬁnd that these changes do not aﬀect the likelihood of searching, but do lead to large yet very transitory spikes in search eﬀort by individuals already looking for work. These results are not driven by changes in the composition of searchers.
